title: Arduino Mega / Mega 2560 / Due Drilling And Mounting Plates

description.text:
This thing contains a mounting plate and a drilling guide for the “Arduino Mega / Mega 2560 / Due Drilling And Mounting Plates”.   
The plates are not symmetrical. The notch shall be on the power jack and ethernet cable side. The base plate is 2 mm thick. M2 5 mm or 1/4″ 4-40 screws are needed to fasten the board to the mounting plate. The mounting holes are three mm in diameter.  
The holes do not go through the lower layer to make it easier to print. You will have to drill them.   
The post near pins 21-22 on Arduino_Mega_Mounting_Plate.stl is one mm lower.  This was needed because of the nearby soldering pads.  The V2 version has a 5 mm post like the others.

title: Geeetech filament spool bushing for 20mm center pipe

description.text: This is my very first drawing, but I'm a fast learner. It is too small in stl but, I scaled it to fit in slic3r gcode, details below. I drew this up so that my filament spool unwinds just a bit smoother. I did not smooth out the flat ridges because I didn't want it to just keep going on momentum but without really restricting movement. GCODE: I ran it at 15% infill, Slic3r for marlin firmware flavor. I enlarged drawing to 1.1 on x axis and y axis but, kept z axis at 1.0 when I slic3d it so it would fit correctly. didn't have a micrometer yet. 04/20/2015

author: tsmith77

description.text:
Extruder direct drive MK7 and MK8 gears.
For filaments 1.75mm and 3.00mm
Easy to print and assembly.
Strong pieces. New version, handling and printing improvements. You can help me to do more things like this.
Buy my designs at pinshape:http://pinshape.com/users/27920-jsirgado
The OpenSCAD file is there, you can change all.

What you need:
3x - screw 3mm diameter 10mm height (motor).
1x - screw 3mm diameter 30mm height (motor and arm).
1x - screw 4mm diameter 15mm height (bearing).
1x - screw 4mm diameter ~40mm (arm and coil).
1x - bearing 22mm diameter, 8mm hole diameter 7mm tall.
1x - coil ~6mm diameter, ~5mm hole diameter ~10mm tall.
1x - mk7 or mk8 drive gear.
Lots of nuts and washers. Attention:
1 - Is recommended use a fan to cool the motor.
2 - For the 3mm filament, it will not work well with weak motors.
3 - Use one washer between the body and the arm, in the arm rotation screw.
4 - For the bearing axis, the total height (washer + nut + screw) CAN NOT be higher than the bearing (maximum of 7mm), use more washers in the screw head to fix it.

title: Darth Vader bust with optional helmet accessory!

description.text:
This is a very quick and VERY dirty model of Darth from the shoulders up. It's probably way too over designed and as such must have hundreds of unused vertices but i'm lazy and probably won't ever try and fix any. Hence it's up here as it is now. My Thing-O-Matic isn't properly calibrated and is using some old ABS stock I had lying around so the prints look average. I'm totally keen to get this printed again once i'm through with my upgrades and can get her all sorted out and on the straight and narrow again.
It was an attempt to try and get a Darth Vader bust similar to the beethoven one but ended up being more of an experiment on how I could print the model with little to no support structure. I tried to print him without separating the helmet and had limited success (see the totally red Darth images). The helmet bottom rim didn't print nicely for a bunch of layers so makes it a bit wobbly looking. 
No matter what I do I can't get my ToM to print any support structure so my fabrications always look a little worse for wear on overhangs in images...
The VaderBody.stl really needs some support under the chin, but is otherwise easy to deal with. 
VaderHelmet has some in-built support in the design so that you can print it without needing to use other support and hack it out of the inner helmet. 
I like to cut away the chin of the VaderBody.stl, after printing with no support as it's a little cthulu-like, and use a lighter about an inch from the model to re-set the ABS and get rid of the white from my trimmings. Again It's not perfect but it works.
So yeah, i've already said it, but it isn't perfect and I welcome others to alter and fix things if they feel the need/desire. Perhaps Darth might be lucky enough to get some more accessories in time too...

• Print VaderHelmet with NO support structure.

  • Print VaderBody WITH support (or if you're special like me just leave it out and it sorts itself out)

  • Place helmet on Vader and admire his dark brooding look.
    • My Darth quite likes to perch upon my ToM and look down upon my fabrications with an air of disdain and admiration. Assuming i'm not printing yoda.... ooooh yoda, that gives me an idea.

comments.text: Please could you repair the helmet STL model? It gives me lots of errors and the outcome is always messed up (as Dannation said as well...). I tried it with Skeinforge and Slic3r alike.

description.text: Coasters? Wall decorations? Math swag? Ninja stars? You decide. These models were made from Spirograph drawings using the new Shape Maker tool in the MakerBot PrintShop iPad app. Step 1: Draw geeky math shapes with a Spirograph. Step 2: From the PrintShop Shape Maker app on your iPad, take a picture of your drawing. Step 3: Export and 3D print! I resized all of the demo models to have 2mm height. But don't just print the demo models; go make your own! =====

title: iphone 6 plus mount for coffee cup holder

description.text: This iphone 6 plus mount is made to fit my phone that is housed in a Armorbox case I bought online. It slides in easily without having to take off the case. I included an image of the case so you know what it looks like. I use this mount all the time in my wife's Prius and it works well. The cup that it is attached to has a hole in it to keep quarters for meters.

Note that you should not need any adhesive between the mount back and the 45 or 60 top. That way you can pull it off or rotate it for portrait vs landscape modes.   
I use the 45 degree mount but you can choose whichever one you like better.  
The mount back attaches to the iphone mount via M3 screws used in computer cases.   
The top of the cup and cup need to be glued. Nothing else.

author: thor4231

title: 7 Habits of an Effective Leader in Gears

description.text:
My son's school is studying the 7 Habits so I decided to make gears with the habits in them.
Update April 28, 2015 I added a photo pf the finished product. My son and his principal printed them at the actual size from a makerbot printer. After looking at these in actual form you will most likely need to make them bigger before printing them.

I used the free version of Autodesk 123 to create them. I chose a gear from the free objects and added the text. After extruding the text I saved them as .STL files. I also took them into Netfab to make sure they were water tight. The gears are pretty small so you may need to upscale them in your slicer software. I was able to get all 7 on a makerbot platform at 2 inches a gear.

title: Ergonomic handle for metal saw blades

description.text:
I really liked how buckyball's jigsaw blade handle felt in my hand, so I designed something simillar for regular metal saw blades.   
The latter are thinner and longer than jigsaw blades and have smaller teeth usually. They achieve better results in specific cases, but they must be used with care so as not to bend them too much.  
Actually, it may be convenient to break or cut a blade to make it shorter (or recycle a broken one!).

Print it without over-extrusion else you will have hard time inserting the blade in its slot. It is probably better to use a nylock nut then to lock the blade in place (with a 20mm M3 screw) because it is bigger. I sliced it with cura and the following values:
  • 0.2mm layer height
  • 1.2mm wall thickness
  • 1.6mm bottom/top layer height
  • 10% infill (the thing has inside support structures, and the head is mostly empty)
    Less than 1 hour to print at around ~60mm/s
    • Since the "bottom" end is somehow small, I added a kind of homemade raft into the design to secure the print. Do not add araft then (the thing I added is way less messy to remove: just cut the 4 tabs around the head). The code is a complete rewrite in openscad, not really a derivative. But I recycled buckyball's main dimensions for the ball and height, so I marked it as a derivative. If you need to tweak some dimensions, every value is factorized and commented in the source code, it should be straightforward.

comments.text: Just looking at this I'd be concerned about what happens if my hand slips when pushing the blade forward.  There's no sense of a guard.  Seems it's designed for general use, would look for a bump or some lip.  Just a thought!
comments.author: jewzaam

comments.text: I think there is a very small chance you ever cut yourself on a metal saw blade like the one above (the soft nature of flesh will not be easily cut and there is no reason to push very hard forward esp. with such a large handle). But your idea of a guard is still cool, as it would be more ergonomic even, and it would look nicer :) IIRC last time I used it, I pinch the part closer to the blade between the index and thumb and put the biggest part in the middle of the palm, it really feels safe (much safer+sturdier than those flat handles that can be bought for a few bucks).

I built this as a proof of concept part only. Since I haven't tested it
for suitability in actual road and weather conditions, and because
I have no knowlege or control over other peoples' printer quality, I
can't recommend that anyone print this for actual road use. That said, I was having difficulty finding wiper blades to fit my 2011
VW Jetta TDI. The wiper connector on this year's model is
apparently unique and hard to fit. While I can go to the dealer
and pay a little over $40 for a set of blades, it feels wrong to reward
them for requiring a proprietary connector on something as simple
as a wiper blade without at least examining ways to use something
more standard. This adapter lets you connect a standard US wiper blade to the
2011 VW Jetta TDI. I printed this one in a tan color so you could see it in the pictures, I
recommend black for most cars, but some people may prefer a color
that compliments their paint scheme. See the instructions tab for print and assembly details

I chose to use ABS as PLA melts in summer temperatures and
cracks easily in the winter. I printed this part with .2mm layers and 50% infill with support. Print these pieces in the orientation they are downloaded. It does
require support as they are positioned, but this orientation minimizes
the risk of the parts cracking during assembly. Once printed, remove the support material and dry fit them together
before gluing. The bottom piece has an alignment groove on each
side near the top that slides into the opening on the other (top) part.
See the second to last picture. Please note that they should fit
together tightly without any play. Once you're comfortable with the fit, put some glue in the four
places indicated by the last picture and slide the parts together. The
glue is what actually holds the parts together, not the alignment
grooves, so be sure to glue it well with an appropriate glue. When dry, install the bottom part onto a standard wiper blade and
install that whole assembly onto the car.

This is a continuation of the inkscape-unicorn plugin. It allows you to draw different layers, which the 3d printer will print and put on top of each other.
This thing is very much a work in progress. I intend to parse the style properly, so I can assign differentiate between different colours and produce gcode for multi-nozzle setups, and interpret the stoke-width as a measure for the track-width. In the end it should be very much what you see on screen is what you get on the printer.
Later on I hope to be able to read gcode, transform it back to svg and have the user edit individual nodes.
A system like Doodle3D.com should also be possible, but a little more precise if you don't have to use a finger+ipad to draw. I'll use github to further develop this thing, which I don't fully understand yet. Here is the link anyway: https://github.com/JelleB/inkscape-unicorn

the source files in the scr directory need to be copied to your inkscape extensions folder. On my computer that was C:\Program Files (x86)\Inkscape\share\extensions, ymmv.
Make a drawing and select >save as>|3D pinter gcode
It will pop up a window with some settings, change them as you please. click on and you will end with a .gcode file that can be printed on a (reprap style) 3D printer.
I used an Ultimaker to test against, which runs a recent version of marlin. If you use another firmware, you might need to modify the startup code and/or some of the actual python/gcode itself. Again, ymmv.

title: Geeetech I3 pro B 8mm Acrylic Electronics Enclosure

description.text:
I designed this enclosure to help protect the electrical cables from young prying fingers. This enclosure also serves to direct the cooling fans between the Arduino and Ramps 1.4 boards. The enclosure features side and rear venting, a cutout for the USB cable and X axis motor. The mounting flanges make use existing holes that remained after mounting the Arduino and Ramps 1.4 boards.  I placed only two mounting flanges so as to make the installation around the zip-tied cables much easier.  
I recommend raising the Z axis about 50 mm before installing the enclosure. This simply moves the motor out of the way during installation.  
I used Blue PLA that seemed to match the printed parts that came with the Geeetech I3 Pro B model.  
You will need to use some support material for the flanges to print properly.  
This enclosure does consume much of the build plate. I used a 2 mm skirt, and it barely fit on the bed. Overall size is approximately 4.25" x 3.25 x 7.5" (108 x 83 x 190)

This part is pretty straight forward.  I do recommend printing this part with support material to support the mounting flanges.  
Raise the X motor approximately 50mm before attempting to install the box. This ensures the motor does not bind the box against any of the cables during the installation process.  
Use a light fill 5-10%

I needed to create a way to provide a serious amount of cooling for my TAZ 5 / Hexagon hotend. The little "squirrel cage" fan was just.... cute. No offense to the Taz designers! I LOVE my machine :) But seriously, that small fan was way too small, and it was actually really noisy. So, as all good do-it-yourselfers would do, I designed and printed my own along with a Filament Tube Retainer. The Filament Tube Retainer is a modified version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:766614 created by Wolfie, and the fan shroud is my original design. The intent of the shroud is to provide as much air flow across the cooling fins right above the heater block in the hotend itself, while preventing any airflow across the heater block. I also wanted to provide some additional air flow across the entire filament feed assembly, but I wanted it to look and feel as if it were a stock item. The shroud itself went great, but I realized that I wanted to keep the filament tube retainer that I had (Wolfie's design), plus I needed a way to anchor the top of fan shroud. Slight design change = win.

The mounting points of the fan shroud are 3 existing points on the extruder assembly. The stock "squirrel cage" fan will need to be removed completely, and is no longer needed. The first one is the small unused threaded hole just above where the "squirrel cage" fan was. The second uses the stock bolt the holds the hotend base left side. And the third attaches to the filament tube retainer. I printed mine using Cura with the "PLA_cura_fine" profile from Lulzbot slightly modified. I've included the profile as well. This is a CURA only profile. For more specific details, please refer to my complete posting on the Lulzbot forums at https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=36&t=2054 I used a standard 80mm cooling fan from an old computer I had. I also used the power supply from the same computer to run the fan. I did this because I wasn't comfortable with pulling a strong 12 volt source from the main board of my TAZ 5. For now I have a manual on/off switch for the fan.

Here is a Pan and Tilt Gimbal, with a retractable main frame. The dome is a snap-on fit to the rotation ring, allowing for quick and easy access to the Mobius to start and stop recording, power on and off, switch modes, etc. When utilizing the retractable mainframe, the pan servo is mounted on an vibration, isolation bracket, which helps reduce the amount of vibration transferred from the aircraft. The mainframe is capable of lowering the dome 45mm below the mounting surface, as well as raising it completely above for retractable operations. This is currently in BETA form, and will require a bit of DIY tweaking. All bolt holes are designed for 3mm bolts and nuts, using nylon washers to separate moving components. It operates via 3 HS85 servo's, or equivalent. If you plan to use this gimbal on a multi rotor or any other use that would not utilize the retract function, simply mount the pan servo directly to your vehicle. YES, I am aware that this print is of very low quality. It was printed quickly for proof of concept, with humid ABS filament resulting in a very rough print

This requires 3 HS85 or equivalent servos, 3 rubber/silicone vibration dampning balls, and 3mm bolts, nuts, and washers (Ideally 2x 14mm, and 8x 18mm). Files to print:
Isolater and arms (x1)
Dome (either ventilated or not)
Main Frame and Isolation frame (or each individually)
Mobius Cradle
Rotation Ring. Assembly should be pretty self explanatory, but let me know if you need any help! I tried to make the entire system as versatile as possible without limiting the user to one type of servo. Unfortunately this couldn't be done for the pan servo, as it has to be specifically centered, therefore it was designed for an HS-85. As far as the tilt servo, it is intended to be glued underneath the mobius cradle. I will post a picture back on the original page. Essentially the servo is glued to the bottom, and you create a control rod going from the servo arm, to the blank space forward of the tilt pivot, on the rotation ring. (does this make sense?) Same goes with the retract servo. It was designed for you to use whatever servo you can manage. You simply need to drill a small hole in either an upper or lower arm, and glue the servo to the base plate. Again, location of the hole depends on the location and size of the servo and control rod.

title: Covered Bulb Socket Element
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Update : I have redesigned an interlocking variant : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7857 This is designed for lamps where the light-bulb is inside a polyhedral shell. This is a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6055. The hinged piece has been mirrored, and pieces to cover the socket have been added. The covering pictured is built up out of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6281 these elements. It took me some time to build a permanent light socket for this design. The biggest pitfall is that the light-bulb is difficult to replace. Perhaps future designs will correct this shortcoming. A threaded or slotted design, perhaps ?

For now the pieces must be held together with super-glue. Please see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6055 for more instructions. Note that the outer cover (hex_outer.stl) should be attached to the hinged element (illumi1-flipped.stl) before wiring in the socket, if the writing has a plug that cannot fit through the outer cover. See the screen-shot http://www.thingiverse.com/image:51569 for an exploded view of how the pieces assemble. If you want to use this as pictured, use the back-panel with the slot ( panel 1 ), and do not glue the panel in place. The panel interferes with the hook on the socket such that it cannot attach to the chain. Hook the socket onto the chain first and then slide the back panel into place. I will post a more detailed assembly instructions and pictures once I construct a new lamp from scratch. I will probably post this dodecahedron-encased lamp design as a separate thing later, once I write it up. note on hinge clearance : The hinges can sometimes be a little tight. Make sure the first layer isn't pressed too far into the build platform. A compressed first layer will propagate up and make part of the hinge wider, decreasing the clearance. These parts are designed to fit tightly and may require pliers to assemble. If all else fails, removing some of the pins on the hinges can make assembly easier.

description.text:

description.text: This is a miniature 75x26x10 mm model of a grandfather clock with a key chain version. I had some issues with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7594 printing so I remade an heavily influenced version from scratch. Props to themitch22 for the original work. My first modeling project at all in 123d, hopefully its not a complete train wreck to work on. Hopefully it prints nicely for you too. enjoy!

Example print is on a lulzbot mini in PLA on easy mode high quality settings. I wouldn't recommend scaling too much smaller but i guess it is dependent on your printer.  You may want to alter the dial position with more relief to have it show up a bit better.  Time is 4:20 for comedy value, but easily remodeled if you want.  
the keychain portion seems reasonably strong in PLA but haven't really tested it for daily use.

title: Standard 623ZZ ball bearing flange
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: I recently ordered some F623ZZ flanged bearings for a Kossel printer build, but was shipped standard 623ZZ bearings by mistake. I elected to use them and designed this simple part to serve as a flange for the bearing. I tapped the inside with M3 thread so they would stay firmly in place.

I use these with an M3 thread tapped inside. This allows you to tighten them up against the printed bracket so they stay firmly in position without flopping around.  
There is a shoulder that will contact the inner race so that the bearings  will always spin freely.

(click on the thumbnail for the full-length photo) This is an internet-controlled pet treat dispenser. The model pictured has dual chutes and canholders so it will dispense two treats simultaneously, since we have two cats. That's not a necessary component, you can use a single shaft and canholder. The idea here is to put a webcam where it can view the dispenser, possibly something to make a noise to attract the cats, and then give them a treat. In our case, the 'webcam' and noise will be provided by a Rovio. The electronics are arduino-based and can be attached directly to a PC via USB or controlled more remotely with a bluetooth dongle. There is a (very) simple Perl CGI that will activate the pet feeder over the internet. For the record, the plastic used in my photos is:
Blue and Green PLA from: http://diamondage.co.nz/pla.html
Natural PLA from: http://www.makergear.com/products/filament Printed on my Thing-O-Matic. WIP WHY:
  • Not completely tested, but it WILL be complete by the end of the day, with more photos and demo videos!!
  • The joiners I was experimenting with in the STLs below are not really good, especially the part with 4 is basically impossible to get together, although it may work a little nicer in more flexible ABS; these prints of mine are all PLA.
  • My initial tests show the treats I'm using are tend to jam up in the canister instead of falling into the hopper. My initial plan to fix this is to chop up the treats into smaller bits by hand and load them in the canisters. If that does not work, I may have to resort to printing the entire mechanism somewhat larger, and/or designing some kind of agitator for the canisters.
  • Documentation below obviously WIP.
  • Software to be (written and then) provided!
    • QUICK UPDATE: Testing various treats, sizes, shaking the cans, and stuff... we're stuck with the problem that the treats bind up in the can instead of falling into the holes. The next step in solving the problem will be to add some kind of better agitation to the treats that are still in the can. This will require redesigning some of the parts, unfortunately, which I'm doing now. UPDATE (2011-04-18): I've got a new design for the gears, gearbox, and canholders that might help alleviate the jamming problem. I'll post them after a test.
  • supplemental:
    I posted the parts, although they are untested and still printing here.
    • UPDATE (2011-04-20): New parts tested and they work MUCH better. I think it could still be improved somewhat, and there's a bit too much room in some places, but I can probably run with this design as-is.

Hardware:
  • NEMA17 stepper motor (I am using a spare stepper from a cupcake)
  • M8x? + matching nut and washers = main gear shaft
  • 608 bearing = main gear center
  • (4) M3x? = attach stepper motor and spacer block
  • (4) M3x? = secure gear housing
  • (8) M3x10+ = attach canister holders and drop chutes
  • (1) M3(?) set screw = secure small gear to motor shaft
  • All M3 components should fit snugly with no nuts, but you can add nuts if you like in most places.
  • TBD: electronics housing
    • Electronics:
  • Arduino of whatever sort, or Atmega and a bit of work.
  • 7805 Voltage Regulator
  • 12v Stepper Motor Controller; any should do. I am using a Pololu.
  • 12v power supply; if running from USB you might just tap into the computer's PSU.
  • optional Bluetooth serial dongle; there's a nice one for about $13 at mdfly.com I'll be using.
    • Instructions:
    Print 1 of each part, optionally 2 of the canholders and drop chutes. Assemble in the obvious fashion - I can be more detailed if needed. Some tips for construction:
  • Put the cans in with the machine upside-down. I had a nasty spill and treats went everywhere -- the pets enjoyed that.
  • Thread the M8 bolt through the motor housing before you attach anything else. If it is tight enough to hold but loose enough to screw in and out with your fingers, that's perfect. It should be like that after the first time you put the bolt through.
  • The can holders should hold the lids very tightly, so they will not come out; instead when it is time to replace the can, unscrew it from the lid and screw in a new can. Do this with the apparatus upside-down, of course.
  • If you cut away parts of the lid like I did... cover the can with something while you are working, or you may notice it's attracted some attention (see photos).
  • If you have trouble with the joiner tabs, use a big C-clamp to force them in. YOu can use quite a lot of force.
    • Install the provided firmware on the arduino and wire it up as shown (WIP!)

description.text:
3D model of the GI Joe HQ I had when I was a kid.  I created the file using my old toy and a set of calipers so the model should be reasonably accurate.  Like the other GI Joe files I've posted they are presented full scale but intended to be printed in the 25% range for best results.  
I've made a few simplifications (most notably the brig) for easier printing.  I cheated a little on the wall detail as well but I'd bet you can only tell if you compare side-by-side with the real thing.  There are a lot of files too but there were a lot of parts and as usual I hate cleaning off supports.  I printed everything except the flag without support, which I suggest you lay horizontal for printing.  
Finally, the part labeled "lift" is intended to reproduce the actual rising floor of the vehicle bay.  Needed for vehicles that can't shoot through the gun slit.

description.text: mix match

Cobra HQ, modeled full scale and intended to be printed in the 25% range.  
I had not even heard of this toy until a week or two ago but I needed Cobra to have a base to match the Joe's base.  As you might have guessed I modeled this using only online pictures for reference but it looks close enough for me.  The biggest change from the toy is the addition of two more defense towers - it looked unbalanced without them.  
The guns on the lower level are the same as in the turrets.  The cone shape cutout on the bottom is intended to save on plastic.
Much respect and gratitude to the men and women of our Armed Forces (past and present).  Your sacrifice allows people like me to live in peace and freedom.  /You/ are the real American heroes.

comments.text:
Very nice work! I can't wait to print this. I had the original toy growing up--and yes the toy version was a bit unbalanced, because it was one of those 80s toy "play sets" with sort of a "front" and "back" that enabled you to point one side toward the "enemy front".
Your version looks great and falls in line with some spins of the Terror Drome seen in the original comics, 80s cartoons and the original 80s animated movie since these other spins showed Terror Dromes that were more symmetrical and often constructed on a much larger scale than the toy design.
Again, I can't wait to print this model and include it in some sort of board game or table top miniatures game. Thanks for evoking some exciting childhood memories!

comments.text: You're welcome, I hope they print easily for you. I have another dozen models I'd like to make but I have some higher priority work happening right now.  I'm sure it will happen at some point.

text = Trebor James

This friendly little gecko looks great on your desk or stuck to a wall with a bit of lightly adhesive putty. Prints at 100% size in less than 30 minutes at standard settings. (it looks great larger, too!) No raft or support is needed on most 3D printers. It's easiest to remove from the print bed if you slide a palette knife or something similarly thin under the tail and gently work your way forward to get underneath the rear toes, then gently continue forward to the front legs to loosen them. Update: The feet are now level and completely flat on the bottom.

A great way to improve both the resilience and the aesthetics of this model is to print the first few dozen layers in (white) semi-flex or PETG filament, then switch to (green) PLA. This makes the feet much less likely to break off. If you are printing in PLA only, resize to 150% for extra strength.

description.text:
"Dr. Jones I presume?" ; Meeple adventurer for outfitting your own board game.

  • Two options; print drjones_single.stl w/support or print the snap-ons together on the build plate. The hat will have a tiny bit of infill support but it scrapes out quickly and can be fused to the meeple body with a little acetone. I prefer the Fedora a little tipped forward.

  • You may have to clean out the hole to insert the handle of the whip; dip the whip handle end into a little acetone and insert it in the hand. Once it's set, you can flip the meeple over and dip the entire whip into acetone to soften it and reshape the curl as needed. This can be done with the Fedora to reshape it with the appropriate curls along the rim if want.

description.text:
Replacement pad for a small grip/trigger/bar clamp.  
It always seems we have to loose one pressure pad on our trigger clamps. Here is a printable replacement pad for a small clamp. This pad is approximately 15mm X 21mm and prints without support for a print and use result.  
I printed this on a Thing-O-matic then lifted it from the heated bed to install on the clamp without any trimming. I did strengthen it with a brushing of acetone to bond the fibers.

Directly print the *.stl then, install and use.  
The sketchup file has two pads. I made one short but, then decided to make a full sized pad. You have both to choose or scale.

Of course you know, this means war! Load this miniature rubber-band powered crossbow with a cotton-swab "bolt", and try your skill in marksmanship at distances up to 10 feet! Others have done this before (e.g. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:509659), but of course I couldn't resist designing my own. This design is simplified from some of the other miniature crossbows you may find. It uses no non-printed parts, save for the rubber band and cotton swabs. You you can omit the "clip" part for a functional design that prints in one piece. If used, the clip helps to retain and align the bolt with the rubber band, improving function and reliability.

The "Clip" part may be omitted, though the crossbow is easier to use with it.   It is printed separately and glued in place.   When gluing, place a cotton swab in the crossbow to act as a spacer to support the clip in the proper alignment.   
The crossbow is designed for a lightweight rubber band, about 1.5mm thick.   
Cotton-swab "bolts" are made by clipping one cotton ball off of a two-ended swab.   
Please use safely, at your own risk.  Do not give to children or adults.  Do not point the loaded crossbow at anyone or anything.  Do not assume that a cotton swab is a "safe" projectile.  Wear eye protection.  In short, maybe just forget about this and go read a book.

I made this for my girlfriend based on this lipstick organizer : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:334128 The size of the nail polish bottles is 29mm x 29mm then I made 30mm x 30mm size.
The holes are made to use less plastic. In the version I printed (see picture), I forgot to put holes in the bottom of it, and it took approx. 4h in 0.4 resolution on my Freesculpt EX2. Feel free to ask if there is anything with that model ;)

This mount has been designed to fit on top of a Tripod (in my case a quick release mount). There is a small hold in the bottom of the mount to screw into the camera mount. Screw it in carefully the first time.
The other bracket is for the UBend to grip to the pole. You may or may not need this depend on your circumstance. The original base was a go pro mount. I stripped the top and added the pole piece and designed the grip.

title: Groove Track Slugs for Native Kayak Groove Track System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are the track slugs for the Native Groove track system that are used in at least the following kayaks:
Native Ultimate
Native Slayer 10
Native Slayer 13 It is designed to hold a stainless steel 1/4" 20 and 1/4" 32 nut (note: hold, not grip) or their respective hex head bolts/screws. Sizes are not exact (measured 5mm is programmed in scad as 6mm) as my printer (ROBO 3D) seems to have accuracy issues but feel free to edit the values in the scad files.

author: fusionstream

title: Remixed HayWagon with room for 6 minis.

description.text: I really liked Herrigold's wagon (linked below for mobile users), but it looks like it couldn't fit more then 3 minis in it. So I scaled it up a tiny bit and cut out some of the bottom panels and posts to make room for the bases of more minis. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:582802 This was a rushed remix, so it's not the best quality.

author: Pawel36

title: Bungee launch hook for radio-controlled gliders and planes

description.text:
A little bungee launch hook for radio-controlled gliders and planes.  
OpenSCAD source is included should you wish to change any of the parameters.

Print with support material, which snaps off easily for a change.  
Cut a thin groove in the underside of the fuselage ( to accommodate only  the triangular section) and use glue of your choice ( I used hot-melt) to fix the hook in place at or slightly forward of the CG.  Remember that the hook for the bungee should be at the aft-end.

title: A horn for control surface of radio-controlled gliders and planes

description.text:
This is a parametric control horn for radio-controlled gliders and planes. Edit the included OpenSCAD source to change any of the parameters such as:
  • Number of holes
  • Hole radius
  • Height of the first hole above the surface
  • Overall thickness ( strength / weight trade-off)
  • Length of the base where the horn is attached to the surface
  • Amount of the base to push in to or through the control surface

Cut a hole in the control surface to accommodate the squarish section and glue in place with your favorite glue.  The line through the centers of the holes should pass through the hinge of the control surface.  
The gusseted part should lie flat on the surface once the horn is affixed and helps to keep the horn at right-angles to the surface.

author: letsburn00

title: Parametric OpenSCAD Clock Gear Train (Hours, Minutes & Seconds)

description.text:
Extended the previous Proof of Concept for the printable clock to include the entire gear train. 
I had to use a total of eight pinion wheels, four to gear down from the escapement/seconds wheel to the minutes wheel, and another four for the hour wheel (5,3,2,2). Two would make for high gear ratios (10,6 or 8,7.5 typically) which are hard to print, and three would make the minute hand run counter-clockwise.
I wrote the OpenSCAD script so that all the wheels are equidistant (by adjusting the tooth size pair by pair) and so that the gear train can be bent at each wheel in order to stack the second, minute and hour hands on top of each other (e.g. with four wheels between hands, you need to fold by 90 degrees between each wheel). 
It is all fully parametric for that distance, the fold angle, the gear ratios, and number of teeth for each wheel... and you can animate the gear train, they will all rotate at the correct speed and mesh.
The only thing I was not able to do is to make the code recursive, because OpenSCAD does not support that. Booh!

Feel free to play with the OpenSCAD script and try different configurations:
Set the fold angle to zero to lay out the gear train for a looooong clock.
Remove the first two gears, adjust the remaining six gear ratios to something like 5,4 & 3, and make the fold angle 120 degrees for a triangular clock with retrograde minute hand.
Remove the first four gears, adjust the remaining four gear ratios to something like 8 & 7.5, and make the fold angle 180 degrees for a more typical two-arbor clock.
(EDIT: I've added a OpenSCAD script, some JPEGs and an STL of a two-arbor clock with gear rations 10-6-10-6, and open-face gears. Just because.)
Last friendly warning: on my two year old Thinkpad, the eight wheel gear train takes 12 minutes to process in OpenSCAD. :-)

comments.text: Is there anything you'd like the greater Thingiverse community to do to help you on this project? I just thing this is so awesome and can't wait to print out a grandfather style clock!
comments.author: bre

comments.text: Thank you! I think multiple heads are better than one, so anyone with an interest in clocks is certainly welcome to grab the escapement library and play with it... ad majorem thingiversi gloriam.
